ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Greek films, and Greek history through the lens of the films. As a non-humanities major, this class was a strong complement to my normal courses and provided me with new skills for developing insights from and understanding films.
Understanding and analysis of avant garde films, writing about film, understanding Greek history and culture
Ability to analyze movies in a deeper way and to analyze movies differently than how I analyze written texts

We learned a lot about Greek cinema of the last twenty years, Greek identity, and financial crisis. I also developed my ability to write about film and apply theory from the social sciences to discuss films.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths of this course were its thoroughness and the knowledge of the Professor. Additionally, I really appreciated that Professor worked to bring one of the directors of the films we watched into the class to speak with us and teach us, it was an extremely unique and valuable experience. 

Weaknesses - location of the classroom, and I would have preferred two 50-minute classes a week, one for before viewing the film and one for after.

The course format is very straightforward and each movie was clearly selected for approaching the theme of the class from slightly different angles. Students were encouraged to dictate their own opinions in the course, but often the discussions were held up by the professor's comments (not complaining, his insights were very valuable)

Strengths -- fun movies, fun professor, not intense, lots of opportunities to provide your thoughts, good engagement

Weaknesses -- N/A unless you're someone who needs a very structured course

I enjoyed the selection of films, but secondary source readings were generally not very helpful. I was also often frustrated in class by the leminar format. I wanted to hear more from my classmates, but the professor tended to dominate the conversation. Each comment from the undergrads was responded to directly by the professor instead of allowing a classroom dialogue to form.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I loved this course, Professor Syrimis is an amazing professor. We covered many ideas and themes within the course that I believe facilitated my learning and development in other areas that I have not developed at Yale.
I would but definitely prepare to see some intense movies.
Yes, I've really enjoyed the line-up of films and the content of our weekly sections!
Yes! Just be chill about it
I would recommend this course to film studies students and students interested in Greece, migration, or queer representation in film.
